title: Which NFL team will win the NFC South division in the 2020 season?
preds:
For this forecast I will solely focus on the New Orleans Saints (NOS) and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers (TBB). Presently there are 2 matches remaining with ->
NOS = 10/14 Wins - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_New_Orleans_Saints_season#Schedule
TBB = 9/14 Wins - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Tampa_Bay_Buccaneers_season#Schedule In examining the 9 possibilities that NOS and TBB team winning 0,1 or 2 of the 2 remaining matches ->
NOS Wins Division = 6/9
TBB Wins Division = 1/9
Draw = 2/9 Dividing the Draw evenly get ->
NOS = 78% = 7/9
TBB = 22% = 2/9
updating to follow crowd. unsure why i forecasted on this question

As of 8 December, the New Orleans Saints have a 3-game divisional lead in the loss column with four games remaining. In the two regular-season matchups between TB-NO, the Saints swept the series, meaning that the Bucs would need to finish with a better regular-season record than the Saints to finish as division leaders. The Saints' "magic number" to clinch is therefore 1 game...either a TB loss or NO victory results in the Saints winning the division. Despite the Saints suffering an injury to franchise QB Drew Brees, the team has been on a tear and has not lost since 9/27.  The Saints' remaining schedule includes PHI, KCC, MN, and CAR. PHI--a losing and struggling team--just benched their franchise QB (Carson Wentz) and are starting rookie Jalen Hurts in his place.  I predict that NO will clinch Week 14.

Saints defense held it today and QB Hill had a pretty good game with Brees out.  NO is up on the Bucs by three games with four to go.  If they win one more game they will win the Division since they have beaten the Bucs twice during the season.  They should be the Eagles or the Panthers with ease.
The Bucs put up a good show, they were one of my favs this year...  and the good news is, win or lose guess were the Superbowl is going to be

Updating.... Unlikely that NO loses 4 of last 5 games to end at 10-6 with TAM winning out out (4 games left) to go 11-5. If NO loses 3 of last 5 and TAM wins out they'd both be 11-5 - NO takes the head to head tie breaker (2-0). NO - I expect a loss against KC, but wins against ATL, PHI, MIN, CAR (PHI is 50/50) 
TAM - I expect to win out
Saints still playing better than Bucs
Low chance of Bucs winning division now. Saints 2-0 vs. Bucs for tiebreaker https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/upshot/nfl-playoff-picture.html
The Saints have coalesced and the Bucs have lost a bit of steam given recent losses.  At this stage in the season, I don't see the Buccs bypassing the Saints for the lead.
Saints are 4-0 in Division, on 7 game winning streak, and just won with the back-up QB.
Saints playing better; Bucs lost 2 out of last 3

Atlanta is out.  Letting the Panthers hold on by a thread.  Saints still favored to win, but the Bucs have a slightly better schedule based on website below.   http://powerrankingsguru.com/nfl/strength-of-schedule.php

Updating through Week 11. Assuming all games are played. Atlanta (3-7) - out Carolina (4-7) - out New Orleans (8-2) - Even with the injury to Brees (expected back for Week 15 vs. KC), NO should win against DEN, ATL, MIN, and CAR. 50/50 games with KC and PHI. Most likely going 5-1 to finish with 13 wins. Tampa Bay (7-4) - Costly loss to LAR on Monday night in a game they should have won. They should beat MIN, ATL x2, DET. Likely loss to KC. Makes them 4-1 to finish for 11 wins. Even if they run the table and win out, that is 12 wins and NO would need to lose 2 (KC and one other) to end with 12. Should NO and TAM end in a tie, the tie-breaker goes to NO on head to head (won both contests). While still possible for TAM to win the division, it is not very probable.
Big loss tonight for Bucs. Chiefs are next https://www.nfl.com/standings/

"After undergoing X-rays and CAT scans, doctors have discovered Drew Brees has 11 broken ribs. The human body has 24 ribs." https://www.ksla.com/2020/11/22/report-drew-brees-has-broken-ribs/ It doesn't seem to hurt the Saints much, though, the only thing I wonder is, how Brees is going to miss "at least three games" only in a contact sport like AF with 11 ribs broken.

Lowering forecast (for the Saints) somewhat per the Drew Brees injury, for now  FWIW the Saints schedule is not looking especially arduous 'on paper' for the next 3-4 weeks:
https://www.espn.com/nfl/team/schedule/_/name/no https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/drew-brees-injury-saints-qb-getting-second-opinion-to-determine-how-long-hell-be-sidelined-per-report/
Brees is hurt; not sure for how long

Advantage: Saints head-to-head record vs. Bucs (2-0), plus their 6-1 conference record (3-0 in division). Buccaneers also have a potentially tougher game this week vs. Rams https://www.sportingnews.com/us/nfl/news/nfl-standings-playoff-picture-week-10/1o9a657h9qqgq1jweu6p4f3x48
NO holds the tie-breaker and is up a half game on the Bucs.

Assuming all games are going to be played, stats through the end of Week 9. All probabilities are based upon future lines or projected lines. Falcons (3-6)
Most likely wins: none
50/50 scenarios: LV, LAC
Most likely losses: NO (x2), TAM (x2), KC
Most likely final record: 5-11 Panthers (3-6)
Most likely wins: DET
50/50 scenarios: WAS, DEN
Most likely losses: TAM, MIN, GB, NO
Most likely final record: 6-10 Saints (6-2)
Most likely wins: SF, ATL (x2), DEN, MIN, CAR
50/50 scenarios: PHI, KC
Most likely losses: none
Most likely final record: 13-3 Buccaneers (6-3)
Most likely wins: CAR, LAR, MIN, DET, ATL(x2)
50/50 Scenarios: KC
Most likely losses: none
Most likely final record: 12-4 The division really boils down to NO and TAM. Both play KC, both have a fairly weak schedule to finish out the season. It becomes a matter of healthy players and who doesn't lose a game that they should win. NO did beat TAM twice already this season, so even if they end up with the same record, NO would win the tie-breaker.

Tampa was owned...handily...by Brees and the Saints.  Still lots of football yet to be played.  As atlanta starts to get its injured starters back on defense, accept them and Carolina, to start to play spoiler.

McCaffrey injured again, so the Panthers are done, and with the Saints complete annihilation of the Bucs last night, they made the most compelling case yet that they are the favorites to win the division. They now have both head-to-head matchups, which means the Bucs have to beat them outright. With similar schedule difficulties, I think that gives the Saints a huge advantage moving forward.
Well, the Saints put the wood to the Bucs on Sunday.  Which Superman will prevail?  Brees or Brady?

Carolina and Atlanta are playing better football, but with a three win advantage for New Orleans and Tampa Bay, the odds of either the Panthers or Falcons overtaking both the Saints and Buccaneers is less than 1%.
With the Buccaneers recent loss to the Saints and with comparatively weak schedules to finish the season (each team faces Kansas City once), New Orleans has a higher winning percentage and has the tie-breaker of head-to-head wins against Tampa.
Saints have a full game on TB and played much better on Sunday. Also schedules for the rest of the season about the same.

Saints struggling at the moment but basically tied with a head-to-head win with the Bucs under their belt (they have played one less game but have equal losses). The Bucs, however, have done enough to gain an advantage in my mind. They also have the easier of the two games coming up, meaning their record is likely to improve further. Hopefully, however, it'll be a tight finish that goes down to the wire. I suspect both teams will make the playoffs regardless.

Joining the 'crowd' on this forecast . FWIW both TB and NO may have relatively 'easy' schedules left https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/cowboys-and-raiders-have-easiest-remaining-strength-of-schedule-of-all-32-nfl-teams-entering-week-6/ https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-nfl-predictions/ https://www.profootballnetwork.com/nfl-power-rankings-week-8-2020/
Tampa has come out of the gates strong with their new Brady/Gronk additions.
I can’t help it. Brady is just too perfect and my wife thinks he’s cute. So of course I don’t like him.

This is a close call... and i hate to say it... but Brady is showing his form once again.  While NO beat Tampa in the Week 1 opener, with no preseason, we can effectively throw that game out as to how the rest of Tampa's season will go WRT the conference games.  Tampa HANDLED Green Bay, who beat NO in a nail biter in the 4th.  Currently, i give the edge to Tampa.  Carolina is surviving the injury of their star running back.  Atlanta, with the worst record in the conference, made a big front office change.  They will see a few quick wins --this is typical of big changes in management and coaching--but they havent proven any staying power.  Injuries continue to plague the Falcons defense and some of their most potent offensive weapons.

Hate to see it, but Brady and the Bucs looked pretty darn good against a very tough Green Bay team.  Never count out Drew Brees and the Saints, but the Bucs are looking good on offense and defense.  I like the spirit from the Panthers as well.  New coach has them moving in the right direction.  Keeping them in the hunt.
Switching to Slight edge for tampa
With the rise in Covid, the NFL finishing the season is looking dicey.
Tampa Bay offense playing more consistently

And just like that, we have a 3-way 3 and 2 race in the division. Panther's aren't quite as dead as they looked at first, though they haven't had any impressive wins. Unlikely their success is sustainable enough to win the division. The Buccaneers are 1-1 in the division, but their 2 losses come to the division leaders (Saints) and a dominant Bears team. Their offense is so new though that it is difficult to tell whether this success will be impaired as teams get a feel for what they're all about. Tossups go to the reigning champs.

An adjustment here is required because the Buccs are adapting to their new QB much better than expected, but you can't count out Brees' well oiled Saints.  The Panthers and Falcons are off to such a miserable start that only a 180 change will help them.

This is already turning into a two-horse race. The Bucs are a win above the Saints but the Saints have the head to head advantage over the Bus at the moment. Moreover, one of the Saints losses came against the Green Bay Packers, who are undefeated so far this season. At the moment, I think the Saints have a slight edge despite the current standings, but if the Bucs pull out a win this weekend against the Packers that will show me they are real contenders.

Small forecast adjustment upward for Bucs mainly based upon some current 'power rankings': https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/30048217/week-5-nfl-power-rankings-1-32-poll-plus-2020-playoff-chances-every-team https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-nfl-predictions/ https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-power-rankings-week-5-bills-are-the-real-deal

Having spent several years working for the gummint in Louisiana after graduating from the University of Florida, I am pretty sure that "New Orleans Saints" is oxymoronic, while "Tampa Bay Buccaneers" isn't.  One gathers this is not how NFC tournaments are decided, though.

Going to be the Saints or Bucs at this point.  The Saints played the Lions close.  Bucs on a three game win streak.  I think New Orleans has the easier schedule.  Bucs have to play the Packers and Chiefs.

Falcons are plagued with injuries and are 0-3. They weren't expected to do well, but they are playing worse than imagined.. Carolina's best player is out for a few weeks. Tom Brady is still one of the best players in the NFL and they have key additions at running back and receiver. Additionally, since 2002, no team has ever won the division 4 years in a row...the Saints have won it the last three.

"New Orleans started the game without six injured starters after a short night of rest. The Saints had a player test falsely positive for the coronavirus Saturday, leading to another round of tests for players and staff overnight in the Motor City. " https://www.wndu.com/2020/10/05/after-covid-scare-and-little-sleep-saints-rally-past-lions/
Actually dropping the another outcome option it’s too unoredictable
N=18, Atlanta=4, Carolina=5, New Orleans=6, Tampa=3, Other=0. New Orleans +6% because of past three victories.
that's just how i feel because i <3 TB
Still early but I think the Buccaneers can do this, increasing their percentage
Rise for bucks at expense of saints due to results Small Increase in “another outcome” after titans and vikings suspend in person activities Due to covid
Best guess based on current performance.  On the other hand, a lot of football to play and potential injuries could reshuffle the strength of the teams.
Moving Another outcome back down as all other falcons rest negative

Upping another outcome since a falcons player has tested positive for covid. [1] Probably will be contained but thought it justified a small rise. [1] https://www.nfl.com/news/falcons-cb-a-j-terrell-tests-positive-for-covid-19-placed-on-reserve-list
Falcons have no defense; Saints best offense in Division

I provided stats since the NFL-AFL merger of 1970. Some teams joined after that.

1) New Orleans joined the league before 1970. They won the NFC West in 1991 and 2000 before transferring to the NFC South. They won the NFC South in 2006, 2009, 2011, 2017 – 2019 (the last three years) = (8/50). They have the longest Coach/QB relationship in the Division (Payton and Brees).
2) Bucs joined the league in 1976. The won the NFC Central in 1979, 1981, and 1999.  After being transferred to the NFC South they won again in 2002, 2005, and 2007 = (6/46). 
3) Panthers joined the league in 1995: They won the NFC West in 1996.  After being transferred to the NFC South they won again in 2003, 2008, and 2013-2015  = (6/25). 
4) Falcons joined the league before 1970: They won the NFC West in 1980 and 1998. After being transferred to the NFC South they won again in 2004, 2010, 2012, and 2016 = (6/50).
Used the odds from this website: https://www.sportsbettingdime.com/nfl/divisional-odds/#NFCSouth
Small increase for tampa at expense of saints after first couple of weeks results

The loss of key playmaker WR Michael Thomas and defensive line members created weakness in the Saints defense. Thomas is expected to miss another 2-4 weeks, creating the potential for another loss or two. Tampe Bay's defense has proven to be improved over 2019, increasing the possibility of gaining ground on the Saints. Atlanta's porous defense continues to overcome the strong offensive production. Carolina, already destined for last place in the division, lost their elite running back Christian McCaffrey.

The Panthers have already been beaten by the Bucs and the Raiders, neither of which is exactly top talent. They also lost Christian McCaffrey last Sunday and initial reports claim he could be out for several weeks, meaning that their offense will likely be even worse than it has been.
Atlanta finished last season strong but are currently sitting 0-2 after losing to the Seahawks and Cowboys. The former was fairly comfortable for their opponents and while the latter was definitely an attention grabber 'til the end it showed that the Falcons just don't have the winning mentality and cold-blooded finishing capability needed to win a division in the NFL.
The Bucs are trying to make a go with proven talent and it has had mixed results so far. They are already down 1 game to the Saints and have not been truly convincing in either of their games this season. They, however, sit in second with a record of 1-1 for now and have the largest chance of challenging of taking the top spot away from the favorites.
The Saints have proven talent who are accustomed to playing together, a record-breaking quarterback, and a record of winning the division even when the opposition teams were far better than they are now. Injuries are really the only factor here that could change the outcome, but given their depth in most key spots it is unlikely this will be enough to swing the division any other way.
It seems the Falcons should have an evening of rule assessment first... https://www.si.com/nfl/falcons/news/atlanta-falcons-dallas-cowboys-week-2-nfl-six-obvervations

The Saints have won the NFC South the last three years and the only team in their division that has made moves to better this year are the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. The addition of Tom Brady, Fornette and Rob Gronkowski make the NFC South a two-team race. Vegas has the Saints at +100 and the Buccs @ +120.
Revised on Atlanta's loss... they still havent finished how to close out a game when ahead.

I'm a Falcons fan.  With the addition of Todd Gurley, improvements in Calvin Ridley, and defense that saw signficant gains, I anticipate that the Falcons will take the division.  The Saints under Drew Brees look to be the next best bet.  Tampa Bay will see sporadic success under Tom Brady, but we will learn that the Patriots success cannot be completely attributed to the quarterback position.

The New Orleans Saints have a strong defense and a returning nucleus of offensive players familiar with the offensive system and playing with Drew Brees. Tampa Bay has an improved defense, a solid stable of running backs, and the wildcard of Tom Brady. As the team progresses through the season, the offense should gel and Tampa is likely to be in the hunt for a playoff wildcard spot in the NFC. The Atlanta Falcons are likely to pile up points on offense, but the defense is likely to be the downfall leading to a .500 season. The Carolina Panthers are in a rebuilding year. They have an elite starting running back, but a terrible defense and an experienced, but underwhelming new quarterback and new coach. New Orleans gets a bonus bump in likelihood of winning the NFL South based on the potential for a shortened season due to COVID - their head-to-head victory against Tampa Bay in week 1 nearly ensures that NOLA will claim the NFL South if there's a shortened season.
TB is off to an inauspicious start while the Saints looks pretty good. I expect them to win the division handily. Carolina and Atlanta need work still.
The Saints and Brees are well-tuned, won their first game against the Bucs and Brady.  Buccs will do well under a new Brady but likely remain number two.

Basing my projections off of FiveThirtyEight for now [1], accounting for 5% chance of season ending before any division champion is crowned. Also, if you like forecasting on NFL questions, I just launched an NFL and fantasy football forecasting site [2] with tons of interesting questions like: * How many NFL players will have tested positive for COVID-19 by the end of the season? [3]
* How many total fans will attend NFL regular season games in person in 2020? [4]
* When will the last game of the 2020 NFL season be played? [5]
* Will a sitting U.S. president attend an NFL 2020 season game in person? [6]
* How many tweets from @realDonaldTrump will include "NFL" between September 2020 and March 2021? [7]
* What will be the official name of the Washington Football Team on March 1st, 2021? [8] ...and more! I just launched the platform to family and friends and so would greatly appreciate any of you to come check it out and support it. As you can imagine, building a niche forecasting community is quite a challenge, so I really appreciate your upvotes on this comment and support by signing up and forecasting on some of the questions there! [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-nfl-predictions
[2] https://fantasy.cultivateforecasts.com/challenges
[3] https://fantasy.cultivateforecasts.com/questions/7086-how-many-nfl-players-will-have-tested-positive-for-covid-19-by-the-end-of-the-season
[4] https://fantasy.cultivateforecasts.com/questions/7072-how-many-total-fans-will-attend-nfl-regular-season-games-in-person-in-2020
[5] https://fantasy.cultivateforecasts.com/questions/7060-when-will-the-last-game-of-the-2020-nfl-season-be-played
[6] https://fantasy.cultivateforecasts.com/questions/7074-will-a-sitting-u-s-president-attend-an-nfl-2020-season-game-in-person
[7] https://fantasy.cultivateforecasts.com/questions/7073-how-many-tweets-from-realdonaldtrump-will-include-nfl-between-september-2020-and-february-2021
[8] https://fantasy.cultivateforecasts.com/questions/7068-what-will-be-the-official-name-of-the-washington-football-team-on-march-1st-2021
Wouldn’t be first time Brady tripped me up in a forecast.

Starting with betting odds as base rate and tweaking a little. Can someone help out a new NFL fan, what sort of scenarios might be covered by 'another outcome'? (presumably there is some sort of tie break for tied results)

Saints may be one of the league's top teams. Key injuries, COVID are potential question 'wildcards'. https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/2020-nfl-season-predictions-picking-the-super-bowl-playoff-teams-and-final-standings-for-all-32-teams/ https://nypost.com/2020/09/10/nfl-preview-2020-who-will-win-the-nfc-south/ https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-nfl-predictions/
